com.ojcoleman.ahni.transcriber
Class NEATTranscriberBain

java.lang.Object
  com.ojcoleman.ahni.transcriber.TranscriberAdaptor<BainNN>
      com.ojcoleman.ahni.transcriber.NEATTranscriberBain
All Implemented Interfaces:
Transcriber<BainNN>, Configurable
public class NEATTranscriberBain
extends TranscriberAdaptor<BainNN>
implements Configurable

Constructs a Bain neural network from a chromosome using the NEAT encoding scheme. An ActivatorTranscriber should be used to construct an instance of this class. ActivatorTranscriber.newActivator(Chromosome) is then used to get the resulting network. To use the HyperNEAT encoding scheme see HyperNEATTranscriberBain.

Bain neural networks are not well suited to feed-forward networks as every neuron and synapse must be activated every simulation step. Bain is intended for recurrent networks, however the implementations of Activator.nextSequence(double[][]) and Activator.nextSequence(double[][][]) in the BainNN wrapper are optimised to provide amortised performance over the number of input sequences for layered feed-forward networks.

Author:
Oliver Coleman

Field Summary
static java.lang.String RECURRENT_CYCLES_KEY
          For networks with recurrent connections, the number of activation cycles to perform each time the network is presented with new input and queried for its output.

transcribe

public BainNN transcribe(Chromosome genotype,
                         BainNN substrate)
                  throws TranscriberException
Description copied from interface: Transcriber
Sub-classes must implement this method to convert the genotype to a phenotype, using an existing substrate object to allow performance gains by avoiding destroying and creating large objects or arrays.

Specified by:
transcribe in interface Transcriber<BainNN>
Parameters:
genotype - chromosome to transcribe
substrate - An existing phenotype substrate to reuse
Returns:
phenotype
Throws:
TranscriberException
See Also:
Note: this method has been added to conform with the Transcriber interface, but does not use the substrate argument for performance gains.
